Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: We need to analyze each case sequence against the normative description. Lets break down the rules: - Process always begins with Receive order. - After Receive, next is Check inventory (must occur before any decisions about payment authorization or fulfillment). So Check inventory must be ... before any other activity. However, the timestamp order is given; we can see if any case has something between Receive and Check? No; all cases have Receive then Check next in sequence. So thats fine.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Now, there are two possible paths: 1. If inventory is sufficient (found sufficient after Check): then the sequence should be: Receive, Check, Authorize payment, Package items, Ship order, Close order. ... 2. If inventory is insufficient: then sequence: Receive, Check, Cancel order, Close order.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Additional constraints: - Authorize payment only after Check inventory and before packaging, ... - Package items only after authorization and before shipping, - Ship order only after packaging and never after a cancellation. - Close order final in all scenarios.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Case 1: Activities in order: 1. Receive order 2. Check inventory 3. Authorize payment 4. Package items 5. Ship order 6. Close order This matches exactly the sufficient-inventory path. No violations.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Case 2: Sequence: 1. Receive order 2. Check inventory 3. Package items 4. Authorize payment 5. Ship order 6. Close order ... packaging occurs before authorization. ... Package before authorization is a violation ... So case 2 deviates.

Name: Abductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Case 3: Sequence: 1. Receive order 2. Check inventory 3. Authorize payment 4. Cancel order 5. Ship order 6. Close order This is interesting: After check, they authorize payment, then cancel, then ship ... that implies inventory was sufficient ... But then cancel order appears; ... Also, after cancel, they ship order, which is ... prohibited ... multiple violations: (1) Cancellation after authorization is not allowed ... (2) Shipping after cancellation is not allowed ... So case 3 violates.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Case 4: Sequence: 1. Receive order 2. Check inventory 3. Cancel order 4. Close order This matches insufficient-inventory path: Receive, Check, Cancel, Close. ... So case 4 is fine.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Case 5: Sequence: 1. Receive order 2. Check inventory 3. Authorize payment 4. Ship order 5. Close order Missing Package items activity between Authorize and Ship. ... Package is a required step before shipping. Shipping without packaging is a violation. So case 5 violates.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - IND
Text: Could there be an alternative interpretation? Possibly if inventory is sufficient but they accidentally packaged before authorization? Thats a violation per rules. ... Did they possibly have a scenario where packaging is not needed? ... But the normative description explicitly states Package items as a step ... So skipping is a deviation.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Thus violations: cases 2,3,5. Case 1 and 4 are compliant.
